content:
Interviewer: To start, I would like to begin with a big question: tell me the story of your life. Start from the beginning -- from your childhood, to education, to family and relationships, and to any major life events you may have had.

Aamir Desai: I was born in Mumbai, India, but I moved to the United States when I was just six years old with my parents, who were both working professionals. My father was an engineer, and my mother was a teacher before she decided to stay home with me for a while. Life was different back then—our family lived in a small apartment in a bustling neighborhood, and we didn't have much, but we were happy. My parents always emphasized the importance of education, and I remember being encouraged to read and learn from a very young age. When I was 16, we moved to Edison, New Jersey, which was a big change for me. I had to adjust to a new culture, a new school system, and a new language, but I was determined to make the best of it. I graduated high school and went on to earn my bachelor's degree in computer science from Rutgers University. I've been working full-time as a software developer for the past ten years, and I'm married to my wife, Priya, who is also from India. We have two kids, and we're trying to raise them with the values my parents taught me—hard work, respect, and kindness.

Interviewer: Some people tell us that they've reached a crossroads at some points in their life where multiple paths were available, and their choice then made a significant difference in defining who they are. What about you? Was there a moment like that for you, and if so, could you tell me the whole story about that from start to finish?

Aamir Desai: Yes, there was a moment that really shaped my life. After I moved to Edison at 16, I struggled a lot with the language and the cultural differences. I remember feeling isolated and unsure of myself. But then, during my sophomore year of high school, I joined the school's computer club. That was the turning point. I had always been interested in technology, and being around like-minded peers helped me gain confidence. I started learning English more seriously, and I even took extra classes after school to improve my skills. Eventually, I got into Rutgers on a scholarship, which was a huge relief for my parents. That decision to join the computer club wasn't just about academics—it opened up a whole new world for me, and it's what led me to the career I have today. It taught me that sometimes, the smallest step can lead to the biggest opportunities.

Interviewer: Some people tell us they made a conscious choice or decision in moments like these, while others say it 'just happened'. What about you?

Aamir Desai: I think it was a conscious choice, but one that felt almost inevitable at the time. I remember sitting in that computer club meeting, surrounded by kids who were just as curious and passionate about technology as I was. It wasn't just about the coding or the projects we worked on—it was about belonging. I had spent so much time feeling like an outsider, and that club gave me a sense of purpose. I made a decision then and there to push myself harder, to not just survive but to thrive. It wasn't easy, but I knew that if I didn't take that step, I might never find my place. In a way, it was both a choice and a calling.

Interviewer: Do you think another person or an organization could have lent a helping hand during moments like this?

Aamir Desai: Absolutely, I think someone or something could have made a difference. In hindsight, I wish there had been more support for immigrant students in our school—maybe a mentorship program or a counselor who understood the challenges of adjusting to a new culture and language. I remember one teacher, Mr. Thompson, who noticed I was struggling and offered to help me with my English. He didn't just correct my grammar; he encouraged me to think critically and express myself. That kind of support meant the world to me. I also think organizations like the local library and community centers played a role. They offered free English classes and after-school programs that helped me feel more connected. It wasn't just about academics—it was about feeling seen and supported. I don't know if I would have found the computer club without that kind of encouragement, but I do know that having someone believe in me, even when I didn't believe in myself, made all the difference.

Interviewer: Moving to present time, tell me more about family who are important to you. Do you have a partner, or children?

Aamir Desai: Yes, I'm married to my wife, Priya, and we have two children—Rohan, who's 8, and Aisha, who's 5. Priya is a nurse, and she's been incredibly supportive throughout my career and personal life. She's also from Mumbai, so we share a lot of cultural ties, but we've also built our own life here in New Jersey. Our kids are bilingual, speaking both Hindi and English, and we make sure they understand their roots while also feeling at home in this country. Family is everything to me, and I try to be present for them as much as I can. Even with my busy work schedule, I make it a point to have dinner with them most nights and to take them to cultural events or festivals that celebrate our heritage. I think it's important for them to know where they come from, but also to feel confident in who they are here.

Looking back on the recent interview topics from questions 1 to 5, I realize how much my journey has been shaped by both personal choices and the support of others. From my early years in Mumbai to adjusting to life in the U.S., my family's emphasis on education and hard work laid the foundation for who I am today. The moment I joined the computer club in high school was a conscious decision that changed the trajectory of my life, and I'm grateful for the teachers and community resources that helped me along the way. Now, as a father and husband, I strive to pass on the same values that were instilled in me, ensuring my children feel rooted in their heritage while embracing the opportunities this country offers. It's a balance I'm still learning, but one that feels deeply meaningful.

Interviewer: Are there anyone else in your immediate family whom you have not mentioned? Who are they, and what is your relationship with them like?

Aamir Desai: My immediate family includes my parents, who still live in Mumbai. My father, Ravi, is retired now but was always a strong influence in my life. He taught me the value of perseverance and problem-solving, which I carry with me in my work as a software developer. My mother, Meera, is a graduate with a master's in education, and even though she's been out of the workforce for a while, she's always been my biggest supporter. She's the one who encouraged me to read and learn from a young age, and I think that's why I've always had a passion for knowledge. We stay in touch through video calls and letters, and I visit them whenever I can. My relationship with them is deep and rooted in love and respect. They've sacrificed a lot to give me and my siblings opportunities, and I try to honor that by being the best version of myself. I also have an older sister, Anjali, who lives in Chicago. She's a teacher there, and we're very close. She's been a great role model for me, and I often talk to her about parenting and life choices. Our family is tight-knit, and even though we're spread out, we make sure to celebrate each other's milestones and support one another through life's ups and downs.

Interviewer: Tell me about anyone else in your life we haven’t discussed (like friends or romantic partners). Are there people outside of your family who are important to you?

Aamir Desai: Outside of my family, there are a few friends and colleagues who have been important to me over the years. One person who comes to mind is Sam, a close friend from high school who also joined the computer club. He and I bonded over our shared interest in technology, and even though we took different career paths—Sam went into cybersecurity while I went into software development—we've stayed in touch. He's been a great sounding board for me, especially when I'm facing challenges at work or in life. Then there's my colleague, Lisa, who I've worked with for the past five years. She's been a mentor of sorts, helping me navigate the corporate world and offering advice on balancing work and family. I also have a few friends from the local Muslim community here in Edison. We meet up for iftar during Ramadan and attend cultural events together. It's important to me to stay connected with people who share my values and background, but I also make an effort to be open to new friendships and perspectives. I believe that building a strong support network outside of family is just as vital as the one you have at home.

Interviewer: Now let’s talk about your current neighborhood. Tell me all about the neighborhood and area in which you are living now.

Aamir Desai: I live in a quiet neighborhood in Edison, just a few blocks away from the park where my kids love to play. It's a mix of families from different backgrounds, which I really appreciate. There are a lot of Indian families here, which makes it easier for us to celebrate our traditions and find familiar foods at the local grocery stores. The community is pretty tight-knit, and there are several cultural events throughout the year that bring people together. I also enjoy the convenience of being close to downtown Edison, where there are good restaurants, libraries, and even a few tech startups. It's not the most diverse area, but it's safe, and there's a real sense of belonging. I've lived here for over 15 years now, and while I still miss some of the sights and sounds of Mumbai, I've come to love the rhythm of life here. It's a place where my family can grow, and I can continue to build the life I've worked so hard for.

Interviewer: Some people say they feel really safe in their neighborhoods, others not so much. How about for you?

Aamir Desai: I feel very safe in my neighborhood. It's one of the reasons I've chosen to stay here for so long. The streets are quiet, the parks are well-maintained, and there's a real sense of community. I've never felt threatened or uncomfortable in my own home or while walking around the area. That said, I know not everyone has that same experience, and I think it's important for communities to work together to ensure that everyone feels safe and respected. I'm grateful for the peace and stability we have here, and I hope my kids grow up in a world where safety is a given for all, no matter where they live.

Interviewer: Living any place has its ups and downs. Tell me about what it’s been like for you living here.

Aamir Desai: Living here has had its share of ups and downs, just like anywhere else. On the positive side, the sense of community is something I truly appreciate. There are neighbors who look out for each other, and it's not uncommon to see people helping one another with everything from fixing a fence to sharing a meal. The schools are good, and my kids have made friends from a variety of backgrounds, which I think is incredibly valuable for them. But there are also challenges. Sometimes, I feel like there's a lack of understanding or awareness about the cultural and religious practices of people from different backgrounds. I remember a few instances where my family was asked uncomfortable questions about our traditions, or when we were the only ones celebrating certain holidays. It can be a bit isolating at times, but I try to see it as an opportunity to educate and connect. Overall, I'm grateful for the stability and the opportunities this place has given me and my family. It's not perfect, but it's a home we've built together, and I'm proud of that.

Reflecting on the recent interview topics from questions 6 to 10, I realize how much my family and the community I live in shape my sense of identity and belonging. Talking about my family—Priya, our kids, and my parents—reminded me of the deep roots I have in both my Indian heritage and my life in the U.S. It's comforting to know that even though we're far from Mumbai, we still hold on to our traditions and values. When I spoke about my neighborhood, it became clear how much I value the safety, community spirit, and opportunities that Edison offers. At the same time, I also acknowledged the challenges of living in a place that isn't always fully understanding of different cultures. It's a reminder that while I feel at home here, there's still work to be done to make sure everyone feels included and respected. These conversations have made me more aware of how much my family and community contribute to who I am, and I'm grateful for both.

Interviewer: Right now, across a typical week, how do your days vary?

Aamir Desai: A typical week for me is pretty structured, but it varies depending on work deadlines and family commitments. I usually start my week on Monday with a morning routine—coffee, a quick walk with the kids, and then heading to work. I work from 9 to 5, but I often stay late a few times a week, especially if there's a project coming up. My wife, Priya, usually picks up the kids from school, and we have dinner together most nights. On weekends, we try to keep it family-focused—whether it's visiting a local park, going to a cultural festival, or just having a quiet day at home. I also make time for the Muslim community here, especially during Ramadan, when we gather for iftar or attend events at the local mosque. There are also days when I catch up with friends or attend a tech meet-up, which helps me stay connected to my professional interests. It's a balance, but I think that's what makes life meaningful—having time for work, family, and personal growth.

Interviewer: At what kind of job or jobs do you work, and when do you work?

Aamir Desai: I work as a software developer for a mid-sized tech company in Edison, and I typically work a standard 9-to-5 schedule, though I often find myself working a bit later in the week when there are deadlines or projects that need attention. My job involves developing and maintaining web applications for clients in various industries, from healthcare to finance. I enjoy the problem-solving aspect of my work, and I find it rewarding to see how the software I help build makes a difference in people's lives. I also get to collaborate with a diverse team of developers, designers, and project managers, which keeps things interesting. On some days, I'm deep in coding, and on others, I'm in meetings or reviewing code with my colleagues. I've been in this role for about ten years now, and while the industry changes rapidly, I've learned to adapt and keep growing my skills. It's a demanding job, but I love what I do, and I'm grateful for the stability it provides for my family.

Interviewer: Do you have other routines or responsibilities that you did not already share?

Aamir Desai: Outside of work and family, I also have a few personal routines that help me stay grounded. I try to meditate for at least 15 minutes each morning, even if it's just sitting in silence with my coffee. It helps me start the day with clarity and intention. I also enjoy reading—mostly non-fiction, especially books on leadership, culture, and personal development. I've been trying to read more in Hindi as well, to stay connected to my roots. On the weekends, I like to take long walks with my kids, often ending up at the park or by the river. It's a chance to disconnect from the noise of daily life and just be present. I also volunteer a few hours a month at the local community center, helping with after-school programs for kids from immigrant families. It's a small way to give back, and it reminds me of how much support I received when I first arrived in this country. Those routines, though simple, are important to me—they help me maintain balance and stay true to who I am.

Interviewer: Tell me about any recent changes to your daily routine.

Aamir Desai: In the past few months, I've started waking up a little earlier to spend some quiet time with my kids before the day gets busy. I used to be pretty strict about my schedule, but I've realized how important it is to be present for them in the morning. I've also taken up cooking more often, especially during the week, to make sure we have healthy meals at home. Priya has been supportive of this, and it's been a nice way to bond with the kids over breakfast. Another change is that I've been trying to reduce my screen time after work, which has helped me be more mindful and less stressed. I've also started attending a few more community events, like the local interfaith gatherings, which have been eye-opening and have helped me connect with people from different backgrounds. These small changes haven't been easy, but they've made a real difference in how I feel about my life and my family.

Interviewer: If you have children, tell me about a typical weekday during the school year for your children. What is their daily routine? And what are after school activities your children participate in?

Aamir Desai: A typical weekday during the school year for my kids starts early—around 7 a.m. They both wake up, get dressed, and have a quick breakfast before heading to school. Rohan, who's in third grade, has a pretty full schedule. He has soccer practice after school on Mondays and Wednesdays, and on Fridays, he joins the school's robotics club. Aisha, who's in kindergarten, has a little less going on, but she does have a weekly art class and sometimes stays after school for extra reading time. Priya usually picks them up, and we have dinner together most nights. On the days when Rohan has soccer, we make sure to have a light snack before practice and then head to the field. After practice, we often stop by the park for a bit before coming home. On the days when Aisha has art class, we try to make it a special treat—sometimes ice cream or a fun craft at home. I think it's important for them to have structure and activities that keep them engaged, but I also make sure they have time to just be kids, whether it's playing in the park or reading a book together. It's a busy schedule, but it's also a way for them to explore their interests and grow in a supportive environment.

Reflecting on the recent interview topics from questions 11 to 15, I realize how much my daily life and routines are shaped by the balance between work, family, and personal growth. Talking about my neighborhood and the sense of community reminded me of how important it is to feel connected and supported, not just as an individual but as part of a larger network of people who share similar values. Discussing my job as a software developer and the structure of my week made me appreciate how much I've grown professionally over the years, while also reminding me of the importance of staying grounded through personal routines like meditation, reading, and volunteering. It's amazing how small changes—like waking up earlier or cooking more—can have a meaningful impact on my family life and overall well-being. These conversations have made me more aware of the interconnectedness of my life, and I'm grateful for the stability, opportunities, and love that surround me every day.

Interviewer: Now we’d like to learn more about your health. First, tell me all about your health.

Aamir Desai: In terms of my health, I would say I'm generally in good shape, though I've had my share of challenges over the years. I used to be pretty sedentary in my early career, spending long hours at my desk, which led to some back pain and occasional stress-related issues. A few years ago, I made a conscious effort to be more active, which is why I started walking with the kids every morning. It's not just about exercise for me—it's also about mindfulness and taking time to breathe. I also try to eat as healthily as possible, though I'll admit I have a sweet tooth and sometimes slip up with desserts. I've been seeing a doctor regularly, and I make sure to get my annual check-ups. I also take some supplements, like vitamin D and omega-3s, to support my overall well-being. I think it's important to take care of your body, especially when you're raising a family and trying to stay present in every moment. I've learned that small, consistent habits—like staying hydrated, getting enough sleep, and eating balanced meals—make a big difference in how I feel day to day.

Interviewer: For you, what makes it easy or hard to stay healthy?

Aamir Desai: For me, what makes it easy to stay healthy is having a routine that includes movement, like walking with the kids every morning. It's something I look forward to, and it helps me start the day with a sense of calm. Also, knowing that my health directly impacts my ability to be present for my family gives me a strong motivation to take care of myself. On the flip side, what makes it hard is the occasional temptation to skip a meal or stay up late working on a project. I've learned that when I'm stressed or overwhelmed, I tend to neglect my health, which can lead to burnout. It's a constant reminder that balance is key—not just in my work and family life, but also in how I take care of my body and mind. I've started setting small, achievable goals, like drinking more water or getting to bed by 10 p.m., and I find that these little steps help me stay on track.

Interviewer: Tell me about anything big that has happened in the past two years related to your health: any medical diagnoses, flare-ups of chronic conditions, broken bones, pain – anything like that.

Aamir Desai: In the past two years, I've been dealing with some recurring lower back pain, which I think is related to the long hours I used to spend sitting at my desk. I finally made the switch to a standing desk a year ago, and that's helped quite a bit, but I still have days when the pain flares up, especially after long days at work. I've been seeing a physical therapist once a week, and they've been working with me on strengthening exercises and posture adjustments. It's been a slow process, but I'm starting to feel more relief. I also had a minor flare-up of my seasonal allergies last spring, which made it harder to breathe and sleep well. I've been using a nasal spray and taking antihistamines, which have kept it under control. Overall, I'm managing, but it's a reminder that even small changes in lifestyle and habits can have a big impact on how I feel physically and mentally.

Interviewer: Sometimes, health problems get in the way. They can even affect people’s ability to work or care for their children. How about you?

Aamir Desai: Honestly, I've had to make some adjustments in how I manage my time and responsibilities, especially when the back pain flares up. There have been days when I've had to take it easy at work, which can be stressful because I want to be fully present for my team and my projects. But I've also learned to communicate better with my manager and colleagues about my limitations, and they've been understanding. When it comes to caring for the kids, I've had to rely more on Priya and my parents back home for support during those tougher days. It's not always easy, but it's taught me the importance of asking for help and being flexible. I've also started incorporating more stretching and yoga into my routine, which has helped with the pain and also given me a moment of peace in the middle of a busy day. Overall, I've come to see my health challenges not as obstacles, but as reminders to take things one step at a time and to prioritize what truly matters.

Interviewer: Now we’re going to talk a bit more about what life was like for you over the past year. Tell me all about how you have been feeling.

Aamir Desai: Over the past year, I've felt a mix of emotions—some days I feel grounded and grateful, and other days I feel the weight of responsibility and the challenges of balancing work, family, and personal growth. The pandemic has had a lingering effect, even though things have returned to a more normal rhythm. I've noticed that my kids are more aware of the world around them now, especially with school being more structured and them having more access to technology. It's been both exciting and a bit overwhelming to see them grow so quickly. On a personal level, I've been trying to be more intentional with my time, whether it's spending quality moments with my family, staying active, or reflecting on my own goals. I've also been thinking a lot about the future—what kind of legacy I want to leave for my children, and how I can continue to be a positive influence in my community. There have been moments of stress, especially with work deadlines and the ongoing challenges of being a parent, but I've also found a lot of joy in the small things: watching my kids laugh, sharing stories with my parents back home, and finding time to read or meditate. I think I'm in a good place, but I know there's always room for growth, and I'm learning to embrace that journey with patience and gratitude.

Reflecting on the recent interview topics from questions 16 to 20, I realize how much my health and daily habits are intertwined with my overall well-being and ability to be present for my family. Making small changes like waking up earlier, cooking more, and reducing screen time after work has had a meaningful impact on how I feel both physically and mentally. It's amazing how something as simple as taking a walk with my kids or preparing a healthy meal can create a ripple effect in my day, helping me stay grounded and connected. At the same time, I've come to understand that maintaining my health isn't always easy—there are days when stress or long hours at work make it tempting to neglect my routines. But I've learned that even small, consistent efforts—like drinking more water, getting enough sleep, or stretching when I feel tension—can make a big difference. These reflections have reminded me that taking care of myself isn't just about personal health; it's about being the best version of myself for my family and the life I want to build for them.

Interviewer: Some people say they struggle with depression, anxiety, or something else like that. How about for you?

Aamir Desai: I think I've had moments where I've felt the weight of it all—especially during the pandemic, when everything felt uncertain and the lines between work and home blurred. There were times when I felt overwhelmed by the pressure to provide for my family, to be a good father, and to keep up with the demands of my job. I didn't necessarily struggle with clinical depression or anxiety, but I did experience periods of stress and emotional exhaustion. I remember feeling like I was constantly running on empty, trying to do everything perfectly. What helped me was talking to Priya, who has always been my emotional anchor. She reminded me that it's okay to not be okay, and that asking for help isn't a weakness. I also started seeing a therapist for a while, which was something I hadn't considered before. It was challenging at first, but it gave me a space to process my thoughts and emotions without judgment. I've learned that mental health is just as important as physical health, and I'm more aware now of the need to take care of my mind, just like I do my body. I still have days when I feel stretched thin, but I'm trying to be kinder to myself and to recognize that it's okay to pause, breathe, and take things one step at a time.

Interviewer: How has it been for your family?

Aamir Desai: For my family, the past year has been a mix of challenges and growth. Priya has been incredible through it all—she's been juggling her nursing job, our kids, and even helping me manage my back pain when I'm not feeling up to it. Our kids have been adjusting to more structure in school, which has been both exciting and a bit stressful for them. Rohan is really into robotics now, and he's been talking nonstop about his projects, which is amazing to see. Aisha is still young, but she's becoming more independent, and I love watching her explore the world with curiosity. We've had our share of tough moments, like when the pandemic restrictions first lifted and everything felt so different, but we've also found joy in small things—family dinners, weekend trips to the park, and even just having quiet evenings at home. I think we've all learned to be more patient with each other, and that's something I'm really grateful for. It's not always perfect, but I feel like we're growing together, and that's what matters most.

Interviewer: Some people say that religion or spirituality is important in their lives, for others not so much. How about you?

Aamir Desai: For me, religion and spirituality are deeply important—they are the foundation of who I am and how I navigate life. Being Muslim has shaped my values, my sense of community, and the way I approach both my family and my work. My faith teaches me patience, gratitude, and the importance of helping others, which are values I try to live by every day. Even though I was born in Mumbai and raised in a traditional household, I've found that practicing Islam in the U.S. has been both a source of strength and a way to connect with others in the Muslim community here. I try to maintain my spiritual practices as much as I can—praying five times a day, fasting during Ramadan, and reading the Quran regularly. It's not always easy to balance these practices with the demands of work and family, but I believe that taking time for my faith helps me stay grounded. I also find comfort in the sense of belonging that comes with being part of a larger community, whether it's through attending the local mosque or participating in interfaith events. My children are growing up with an understanding of our faith, and I hope they carry that with them as they navigate their own paths in life.

Interviewer: Some people tell us they use Facebook, Instagram, or other social media to stay connected with the wider world. How about for you? Tell me all about how you use these types of platforms.

Aamir Desai: I use social media in a pretty balanced way. I have a Facebook account where I stay in touch with family and friends, especially my parents and sister back in India. It's amazing how easy it is to share updates, photos of the kids, or even just a quick message to let them know I'm thinking of them. I also follow some local community groups and pages that highlight cultural events or interfaith activities, which helps me stay connected to the Muslim community here and learn more about what's happening around me. Instagram is more for personal inspiration—I follow a few accounts that share motivational quotes, healthy living tips, and even some tech-related content that keeps me engaged with my field. I try not to get too caught up in the endless scroll, though. I've set a rule for myself to check social media only during specific times of the day, like after dinner or on weekends. It's a small way to maintain a healthy relationship with technology while still staying connected with the people and ideas that matter to me.

Interviewer: Some people say they use Facebook or Twitter to get (emotional or financial) support during tough times. What about you?

Aamir Desai: Honestly, I haven't relied much on social media for emotional or financial support, but I can see how it could be helpful for some people. For me, the support I've needed has mostly come from my family, friends, and community. That said, there have been times when I've turned to Facebook or even LinkedIn for advice or encouragement. For example, when I was dealing with the back pain a few years ago, I joined a few online groups for people with similar issues, and it was comforting to read about others' experiences and find tips for managing the pain. I also follow some professional groups on LinkedIn where I can see what others in my field are doing, which helps me feel more connected to my career. I think social media can be a tool for support if used mindfully, but I've always found that the real support comes from the people I know in person. I'm grateful for that, and I try to be there for others in the same way.

Reflecting on the recent interview topics from questions 21 to 25, I realize how much my health and emotional well-being have shaped my daily life and the way I approach challenges. Discussing my recurring back pain and seasonal allergies reminded me of the importance of making small, consistent changes to improve my physical health, like using a standing desk and incorporating stretching into my routine. At the same time, talking about my emotional struggles—like the stress of balancing work and family, and the moments of feeling overwhelmed—has made me more aware of the need to prioritize my mental health as well. I've come to understand that it's okay to not be perfect, and that seeking support—whether from my wife, my therapist, or even online communities—is a strength, not a weakness. These conversations have helped me see that taking care of my health, both body and mind, isn't just about avoiding problems—it's about creating a foundation that allows me to be present for my family, grow in my career, and live with intention and purpose.

Interviewer: Tell me about any recent changes in your level of stress, worry, and your emotional coping strategies.

Aamir Desai: In the past year, I've noticed my stress levels have been more manageable compared to before, largely because I've been more intentional about how I handle challenges. I used to carry a lot of pressure on my shoulders, especially when work was busy or when I felt like I wasn't giving my family enough attention. But I've started using more effective coping strategies—like taking short breaks during the day to breathe, meditate, or even just step outside for a few minutes. I've also been more open about my feelings with Priya, and that has made a huge difference. She's been my anchor, and knowing I can talk to her without judgment has helped me process my emotions better. I've also found that staying connected with my faith and community has been a great source of comfort. Whether it's attending a prayer group or simply reading a few verses from the Quran, these moments help me feel grounded. I'm not perfect at it, and there are still days when I feel overwhelmed, but I'm learning to be kinder to myself and to recognize that it's okay to take things one day at a time.

Interviewer: Now we’d like to talk about how you make ends meet and what the monthly budget looks like for you and your family. What were your biggest expenses last month?

Aamir Desai: Last month, our biggest expenses were related to our kids' activities and education. Rohan's soccer and robotics club fees, along with Aisha's art classes, added up to a significant chunk of our budget. We also had to cover the cost of private tutoring for Rohan in math, as his school's curriculum moves at a pace that's a bit challenging for him. Healthcare was another major expense—my physical therapy sessions for the back pain, along with Priya's nursing supplies and medications, took up a good portion of our monthly spending. Groceries and utilities are always a steady cost, and with both of us working, we also have car payments and insurance to consider. To manage, we've been budgeting carefully, prioritizing what's essential and trying to cut back on non-essential purchases. We also set aside a small amount each month for savings, which helps us feel more secure, especially with the kids growing up and the costs of raising them continuing to rise.

Interviewer: How much did your household spend in the past month? Is that the usual amount? And if not, how much do you usually spend and on what?

Aamir Desai: Last month, our household spent roughly around $5,200, which is actually a bit higher than our usual monthly budget. Typically, we spend between $4,500 to $4,800, depending on the timing of our kids' activities and any unexpected expenses. The majority of our spending goes toward housing, which includes our mortgage, property taxes, and insurance. Then there's the cost of groceries, which can vary depending on how much we cook at home versus eating out. Transportation is another big category—our car payments, gas, and maintenance. We also have regular expenses like utilities, internet, and cell phone bills. On top of that, we set aside money for savings, and we try to contribute to our children's college funds as much as we can. The past month was a bit pricier because of the extra tutoring and activity fees, but we've been careful to track our spending and adjust where we can. It's not always easy, but we've learned to prioritize what's most important and make sacrifices where necessary to keep our family financially stable.

Interviewer: Does your household own or rent your home?

Aamir Desai: We own our home. It's a three-bedroom house in a quiet neighborhood, which we bought about eight years ago when the market was still relatively affordable. It was a big decision at the time, but we felt it was the right step for our family. The mortgage is a regular expense, but we've been able to keep it manageable by budgeting carefully and making sure we stick to our financial goals. We also have a small backyard where the kids play, and it's been a nice space for them to grow up. Owning a home has given us a sense of stability, and I think it's something that will help them feel more rooted as they get older. Of course, it's not without its challenges—maintaining a home, especially with two kids, can be a lot, but it's something we've come to appreciate over the years.

Interviewer: Bills can fluctuate over the course of a year. Seasons change, there are holidays and special events, school starts and ends, and so on. Tell me all about how your bills have fluctuated over the past year.

Aamir Desai: Over the past year, our bills have definitely fluctuated based on the seasons and events. For example, during the winter months, our heating bills went up significantly, and we had to be more careful with our energy usage. In the spring, we had a few unexpected repairs on the roof, which added to our expenses. Then, when summer came around, we spent more on outdoor activities for the kids, like swimming lessons and summer camps. Around the holidays, especially Diwali and Eid, we had to budget for gifts, decorations, and special meals, which can be a bit pricey. School-related costs also vary—when the kids are in session, we have more expenses for school supplies, transportation, and after-school programs. But when school is out, we tend to spend more on family trips or vacations. It's been a learning curve, but we've gotten better at planning ahead and setting aside money for these seasonal changes. I think the key has been being flexible and not getting too stressed when one month is a bit pricier than others.

Reflecting on the recent interview topics from questions 26 to 30, I realize how much my family's resilience and the support I've received from my community have helped me navigate the challenges of the past year. Talking about my family's experiences—Priya's strength, the kids' growth, and the emotional ups and downs we've all faced—reminded me of how interconnected we are and how important it is to lean on one another during tough times. Discussing my health struggles, especially the back pain and seasonal allergies, made me more aware of how physical well-being is closely tied to emotional and mental health. It's also been meaningful to think about how I use social media—not as a crutch for support, but as a way to stay connected with loved ones and learn from others in my field. I've come to appreciate that while online platforms can offer some value, the real support comes from the people I know in person. These conversations have deepened my gratitude for the people in my life and the small, consistent efforts that keep us grounded and moving forward.

Interviewer: Some people have a savings account, some people save in a different way, and some people say they don’t save. How about you?

Aamir Desai: I do save, and it's something I've made a priority for our family. We have a dedicated savings account that we contribute to every month, even if it's just a small amount. It's not always easy, especially with the rising costs of raising kids and the unexpected expenses that come up, but we've learned that even small, consistent contributions add up over time. I also try to save in other ways—like setting aside a portion of my bonus or any extra income from side projects. We've also started a college fund for the kids, which is something I'm really proud of. It's not about being rich, but about being prepared. I remember growing up in a family that didn't have a lot, and I want to make sure my kids have more stability than I did. Saving has become a way for us to build security, not just for the future, but for the present as well. It's not perfect, and there are months when we have to dip into savings for emergencies, but overall, I think it's a habit that's helping us stay grounded and focused on what truly matters.

Interviewer: Some people save for big things, like a home, while others save for a rainy day. How about for you (in the last year)?

Aamir Desai: In the last year, we've been saving for both big things and for the unexpected. The biggest savings goal we have is our children's college fund, which we contribute to every month, even if it's just a small amount. It's something I've been really focused on, especially since I remember how difficult it was for my parents to provide for my education when I was growing up. At the same time, we've also been building an emergency fund, which has been crucial given the unexpected expenses we've had—like the roof repairs and the physical therapy for my back. I think it's important to have both kinds of savings: one for the long-term dreams and one for the short-term surprises. It gives us a sense of security and peace of mind, knowing that we're not just living paycheck to paycheck. It's not always easy, but I believe that saving, even in small ways, is one of the best investments we can make for our family's future.

Interviewer: What is or was your occupation? In this occupation, what kind of work do you do and what are the most important activities or duties?

Aamir Desai: I work as a software developer for a mid-sized tech company in Edison, and my role involves developing and maintaining web applications for clients in various industries, from healthcare to finance. The most important activities in my job include collaborating with cross-functional teams to understand client needs, designing efficient solutions, and writing clean, scalable code. I also spend a lot of time reviewing code, debugging issues, and ensuring that the software we build is reliable and user-friendly. One of the things I enjoy most about my work is the problem-solving aspect—figuring out how to turn complex challenges into functional solutions. I also value the opportunity to learn and grow, whether it's through attending workshops, reading industry publications, or mentoring junior developers. It's a demanding job, but I find it rewarding because I know the work I do has a real impact on people's lives, and that keeps me motivated day after day.

Interviewer: How many hours each week did you usually work?

Aamir Desai: I usually work around 45 to 50 hours a week, though it can vary depending on project deadlines and how much overtime I end up doing. Most weeks, I stick to the standard 9-to-5 schedule, but there are times when I have to stay late or come in early to meet a client's needs or fix an urgent bug. I also do a fair amount of work from home, especially when I need to focus on a complex task or when the kids are home from school. It's not always easy balancing work with family life, but I've learned to be more efficient with my time and to set clear boundaries. For example, I try to leave work at a reasonable hour so I can be fully present for dinner and bedtime routines with the kids. It's a constant juggling act, but I've come to appreciate the structure it gives me and the sense of accomplishment that comes with doing a good job.

Interviewer: Did you have more than one job or business, including part time, evening, or weekend work?

Aamir Desai: No, I haven't had more than one job throughout my career. I've been focused on building a stable life in software development, and while I've taken on some freelance projects or side gigs in the past—like mentoring junior developers or consulting for small startups—it's always been in addition to my full-time role, not as a separate job. I think having one primary source of income has allowed me to be more present for my family and to invest in long-term goals, like our kids' education and our home. I've seen friends juggle multiple jobs, and while it can be a way to earn more, it also comes with a lot of stress and less time for the people you care about. For me, it's been about finding balance and making sure that the work I do aligns with my values and my ability to be there for my family. I'm grateful for the opportunities I've had, and I don't feel the need to complicate things with more jobs.

Reflecting on the recent interview topics from questions 31 to 35, I realize how much my emotional well-being and financial stability are deeply connected to the support systems I have in place. Talking about my stress levels and coping strategies reminded me of how important it is to be intentional with my time and emotions, whether it's through meditation, prayer, or simply having open conversations with Priya. It also made me think about how I manage our household finances—how we prioritize what matters most, like our kids' education and health, while still finding ways to save for the future. I've come to understand that financial stability isn't just about earning more; it's about making thoughtful choices, planning ahead, and being grateful for what we have. These conversations have helped me see that both my emotional and financial health are essential parts of the life I'm building for my family, and I'm learning to take care of both with more awareness and care.

Interviewer: In total, how much did your household make in the past month?

Aamir Desai: In total, our household made approximately $12,000 in the past month. That comes from my full-time salary as a software developer and Priya's income as a nurse. It's a good amount, but it's not always easy to stretch it across all our needs, especially with the kids' activities and healthcare costs. I've learned to be mindful of every dollar we spend, and we've gotten pretty good at budgeting and prioritizing what's most important. It's not about luxury—it's about stability, and I think we've found a balance that works for us. I'm grateful for the opportunities we have, and I hope to continue building a secure future for my family.

Interviewer: Tell me more about your workplace. How long have you been at your current job? How would you describe the benefits that come with your job? (This could include things like health benefits, paid time off, vacation, and sick time.)

Aamir Desai: I've been at my current job for about ten years now, and it's been a journey of growth and stability. The benefits package is pretty comprehensive—health insurance covers both my family and me, which is a huge relief, especially with the kids growing up and the ongoing need for healthcare, like my physical therapy sessions. We also get paid time off, which includes vacation days, sick leave, and holidays. I really appreciate the flexibility they offer, especially with the option to work remotely a few days a week. It's not perfect—there are times when the workload can be intense, and the company culture can feel a bit rigid—but overall, I feel fortunate to have a job that provides security and opportunities for advancement. I've also had the chance to participate in some professional development programs, which have helped me stay current in the fast-paced tech industry. It's not just about the money; it's about the stability and the sense of purpose that comes with knowing I'm contributing to something meaningful.

Interviewer: How would you describe your relationships at work? (How is your relationship with your manager or boss? How are your relationships with your coworkers?)

Aamir Desai: My relationships at work are generally positive, though they've evolved over the years. When I first started, I was a bit reserved, still adjusting to the culture and the fast-paced environment. But over time, I've built strong connections with my colleagues. My manager, Sarah, has been a great mentor—she's supportive, fair, and always encourages professional growth. I respect her leadership and feel comfortable approaching her with questions or concerns. As for my coworkers, I have a good rapport with most of them. We collaborate on projects, share ideas, and even have a few lunch meetings or coffee breaks where we talk about work and life. There's a sense of camaraderie, especially during busy times when we're all working toward a common goal. That said, I don't always agree with everyone, and there have been moments of tension, especially when deadlines are tight or when there's a difference in work styles. But I think that's natural. What matters most is that I feel respected and valued, and I try to foster the same respect for others. I believe good relationships at work are built on communication, trust, and a shared sense of purpose, and I'm lucky to be in an environment where that's possible.

Interviewer: Tell me about how predictable your work schedule is. How would you describe your job in terms of flexibility with your hours?

Aamir Desai: My work schedule is pretty predictable, though there's some flexibility depending on the project. I usually start at 9 a.m. and finish around 5 p.m., but I often stay a bit later a few times a week, especially when we're working on tight deadlines or launching a new feature. The company allows for some remote work, which I really appreciate—it gives me the chance to work from home a couple of days a week, which helps me balance family time better. That said, there are times when the schedule can be less flexible, especially during peak project cycles. I've learned to plan ahead and communicate with my team when I need to adjust my hours, and I think that's helped me maintain a good balance between work and personal life. Overall, I feel like I have enough control over my time to be present for my family while still meeting my professional responsibilities.

Interviewer: Overall, how do you feel about your financial situation?

Aamir Desai: Overall, I feel pretty secure with our financial situation, but I know there's always room for improvement. We've built a stable life for our family, and I'm grateful for the opportunities we've had. My job provides a good income, and Priya's work as a nurse adds to our stability. We've managed to save for the kids' future, and we're careful with our spending so we can cover the essentials without too much stress. That said, I know that financial security isn't just about having enough—it's about feeling confident in our ability to handle unexpected challenges, like medical bills or sudden repairs. I've seen how difficult it can be for families who don't have that kind of safety net, and I want to make sure my kids grow up with more stability than I had. It's not about being rich, but about being prepared, and I think we're on the right path.

Reflecting on the recent interview topics from questions 36 to 40, I realize how much my financial stability and work-life balance are intertwined with the fluctuations in my household expenses and the demands of my job. Talking about how our bills change with the seasons and special events reminded me of the importance of planning ahead and being flexible with our budget. It's not always easy to predict what the next month will bring, but I've learned to be more intentional about how we spend and save. Discussing my work hours and the predictability of my schedule made me appreciate the balance I've found between my career and family life. While I still have days when work feels overwhelming, I'm grateful for the flexibility my job offers and the stability it provides for my family. It's a constant juggling act, but I'm learning to be more present in both my work and personal life, knowing that both are essential to the life I'm building for my children.

Interviewer: Did your mom/dad work for pay for at least a year while you were growing up?

Aamir Desai: Yes, both my parents worked for pay while I was growing up, though their roles were quite different. My father, Ravi, was an engineer, and he worked full-time for a manufacturing company in Mumbai. He was always very dedicated to his job, and even though he didn't earn a lot, he made sure we had everything we needed. My mother, Meera, was a teacher before I was born, but after I was born, she took a break from her career to care for me and my younger siblings. She always said she wanted to be there for us during our early years, and I think that sacrifice made a huge difference in how we were raised. Even though she wasn't working for pay, she was always learning and reading, which inspired me to value education. Looking back, I realize how much their work—whether it was my father's steady income or my mother's quiet dedication—shaped the foundation of our family. It taught me that hard work and sacrifice are deeply tied to the kind of life you build for your children, and that's something I carry with me every day.

Interviewer: What was their job? What kind of work did they do? What were their most important activities or duties?

Aamir Desai: My father's job as an engineer involved designing and overseeing the construction of industrial machinery, which required a lot of problem-solving and precision. His most important activities included working closely with blueprints, troubleshooting mechanical issues, and ensuring that the projects he was involved in met safety and efficiency standards. He often came home tired but always made time to talk to us about his day, which taught me the value of perseverance and attention to detail. My mother, on the other hand, was a teacher before I was born, and she had a passion for education. She loved helping her students understand complex concepts and making learning engaging. Even after she took a break from teaching to care for us, she continued to read and learn, which inspired me to value knowledge and curiosity. Looking back, I realize how much their work—whether it was my father's steady income or my mother's quiet dedication—shaped the foundation of our family. It taught me that hard work and sacrifice are deeply tied to the kind of life you build for your children, and that's something I carry with me every day.

Interviewer: What kind of place did they work for? What kind of business was them? What did they make or do?

Aamir Desai: My father worked for a manufacturing company in Mumbai that specialized in producing industrial machinery for both local and international clients. It was a mid-sized business, and he was one of the lead engineers on several projects. His job involved a lot of on-site work, where he would oversee the assembly of machines, troubleshoot any issues that arose during production, and ensure everything met the required specifications. He also spent a lot of time in the office designing blueprints and working with clients to understand their needs. As for what he made, I don't remember the exact figures, but I know he earned a modest salary that was enough to support our family, though not much more. My mother, before she took a break from work, was employed at a private school in Mumbai where she taught middle school science. She was very passionate about her job and often brought her lessons home, which is how I developed a love for learning at an early age. Even though she wasn't working for pay during my childhood, the values she instilled in me through her dedication to education and her quiet strength have had a lasting impact on who I am today.

Interviewer: We all have hopes about what our future will look like. Imagine yourself a few years from now. Maybe you want your life to be the same in some ways as it is now. Maybe you want it to be different in some ways. What do you hope for?

Aamir Desai: Looking ahead a few years, I hope to continue building a stable and meaningful life for my family while staying true to the values that have guided me. I hope my kids grow up to be confident, compassionate, and curious about the world—just like I was raised to be. I'd like to see them pursue their passions, whether that's in technology, the arts, or something entirely different, and I hope they feel supported in whatever path they choose. Professionally, I'd like to continue growing in my career, maybe take on more leadership roles or mentor others in the tech field. I also hope to be more involved in our community, perhaps through volunteering or helping other immigrant families navigate life in the U.S. I want to be present for my family, to see them thrive, and to make sure they feel rooted in their heritage while also embracing the opportunities this country offers. Most of all, I hope we continue to grow together, with love, laughter, and a sense of purpose.

Interviewer: What do you value the most in your life?

Aamir Desai: What I value the most in my life is the sense of connection—whether it's with my family, my community, or the people I work with. I believe that no matter where you come from or what challenges you face, having a strong support system is what allows you to grow and thrive. I value the love and sacrifices my parents made to give me opportunities, the bond I share with Priya and our kids, and the friendships and mentorships that have shaped my journey. I also value the ability to contribute to something bigger than myself, whether it's through my work, volunteering, or simply being there for someone in need. In a world that can sometimes feel fast-paced and uncertain, I find comfort in the simple things—like sharing a meal with my family, hearing my kids laugh, or being part of a community that uplifts one another. These are the things that give my life meaning, and I hope to continue nurturing them for years to come.

Reflecting on the recent interview topics from questions 41 to 45, I realize how much my financial stability and work-life balance are deeply connected to the structure and flexibility of my job. Talking about my household income and expenses reminded me of the importance of careful budgeting and prioritizing what truly matters—like my family's well-being and our children's future. Discussing my workplace and the benefits it offers, such as health insurance and paid time off, made me appreciate the security that comes with having a stable job. I also came to understand how my relationships at work—whether with my manager or my coworkers—play a role in my overall satisfaction and sense of purpose. It's not just about the paycheck; it's about feeling valued, supported, and having the flexibility to be present for the people I care about. These conversations have deepened my gratitude for the opportunities I have and the balance I've found between my career and my personal life.

Going through this complete interview and life story has been a journey of reflection and gratitude. It reminded me of how much my life has been shaped by the choices I've made, the support I've received, and the values I've carried with me. From my early years in Mumbai to adjusting to life in the U.S., every step has been guided by the lessons my parents taught me—hard work, respect, and kindness. The moment I joined the computer club in high school was a turning point that opened up a world of opportunities, and I'm grateful for the teachers and community resources that helped me along the way. Now, as a father and husband, I strive to pass on the same values to my children, ensuring they feel rooted in their heritage while embracing the opportunities this country offers. My family and the community I live in have played a significant role in shaping my sense of identity and belonging. I've come to appreciate the balance between work, family, and personal growth, and I'm learning to be more present in every aspect of my life. These conversations have made me more aware of the interconnectedness of my life, and I'm grateful for the stability, opportunities, and love that surround me every day.
